{{Year in music|2016}} {{Year nav topic5|2016|Scandinavian music}} The following is a list of notable events and releases that happened in Scandinavian music in 2016.
(Go to [[2015 in Scandinavian music|last year in Scandinavian music]] or [[2017 in Scandinavian music|next year]] in Scandinavian music.) ==Events== ===January=== * '''8''' - The first recording is released of Danish composer [[Hans Abrahamsen]]'s Grawemeyer award-winning work, ''let me tell you''.{{cite news|last1=Huizenga|first1=Tom|title=Hans Abrahamsen Wins The Grawemeyer Award For Music|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/deceptivecadence/2015/11/24/457235043/hans-abrahamsen-wins-the-grawemeyer-award-for-music|accessdate=8 February 2016|publisher=NPR|date=25 November 2015}} * '''15''' - Icelandic broadcaster [[RÚV]] reveals the songs competing to be Iceland's entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] during the [[Rás 2]] radio programmes ''Virkir morgnar'' and ''Poppland''.{{cite web|last1=Bergsson|first1=Felix|title=Öll lögin frumflutt á Rás 2|url=http://ruv.is/frett/oll-login-frumflutt-a-ras-2|website=ruv.is|publisher=[[RÚV]]|accessdate=14 January 2016|language=Icelandic|date=14 January 2016}} Five of the competitors enter English versions of their songs.{{cite web|title=Eurovision hopefuls ditch Icelandic language|url=http://icelandmonitor.mbl.is/news/culture_and_living/2016/02/16/eurovision_hopefuls_ditch_icelandic_language/|website=mbl.is|publisher=[[Morgunblaðið]]|accessdate=17 February 2016|date=16 February 2016}} * '''21''' – The 2016 [[Ice Music Festival]] opens in [[Geilo]], Norway (January 21–24).{{cite web|url=http://www.icemusicfestival.no/7 |title=Ice Music Festival 21 - 24 Jan 2016 |publisher=IceMusicFestival.no |accessdate=2015-04-27 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * '''25''' - The draw to determine which country will participate in which semi-final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] takes place in [[Stockholm City Hall]]. [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016|Sweden]] is pre-allocated to vote and perform in the first semi-final for scheduling reasons.{{cite web|last1=Van Eersel |first1=Dennis |title=Eurovision 2016: Semi-finals Allocation Draw on 25th of January |url=http://www.escdaily.com/eurovision-2016/ |publisher=ESCDaily.com |accessdate=2 January 2016 |date=23 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151225063105/http://www.escdaily.com/eurovision-2016/ |archivedate=25 December 2015 }}{{Cite web|title = Allocation Draw: The results!|url = http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=allocation_draw_the_results|website = Eurovision.tv|access-date = 2016-01-25}} * '''27''' **The Léonie Sonning Music Foundation announces [[Leonidas Kavakos]] as the recipient of the [[Léonie Sonning Music Prize]] 2017.{{cite press release | url=http://www.sonningmusic.org/the-music-prize/2017-leonidas-kavakos.aspx | title=Leonidas Kavakos announced as winner of Léonie Sonning Music Prize 2017 | publisher=Léonie Sonning Music Foundation | date=2016-01-27 | accessdate=2016-01-30}} **The 2016 [[Bodø Jazz Open]] opens in [[Bodø]], Norway (January 27–30).{{cite web |url=http://bodojazzopen.no/?a_id=1118&ac_parent=1 |title=Datoene for BJO 2016 er klare! |publisher=[[Bodø Jazz Open]] |accessdate=2015-04-27}} * '''29''' **The Ernst von Siemens Music Foundation announces [[Per Nørgård]] as the recipient of the 2016 Ernst von Siemens Music Prize.[http://www.evs-musikstiftung.ch/en/prize/prizes/prize-winner/norgard.html Ernst von Siemens Music Foundation page on Per Nørgård] **The 2016 [[Nordlysfestivalen]] opens in [[Tromsø]], Norway (January 29 - February 7).{{cite web|url=http://www.nordlysfestivalen.no/en |title=Nordlysfestivalen 2016: 29. januar til 7. februar |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Nordlysfestivalen]] |accessdate=2015-04-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429072524/http://www.nordlysfestivalen.no/en |archivedate=2015-04-29 }} ===February=== * '''6''' **Opening of the [[Melodifestivalen 2016|56th Melodifestivalen]] in Sweden.{{cite web|last1=Dahlander|first1=Gustav|title=Hit kommer Melodifestivalen 2016 – se alla städerna|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/har-ar-staderna-for-melodifestivalen-2016|website=svt.se|publisher=[[Sveriges Television]]|accessdate=4 February 2016|language=Swedish|date=15 September 2015}} **The first of the [[Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2016]] Semi Finals takes place in Finland.{{cite web | url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=finlands_first_finalists_chosen | title=Finland's first finalists chosen | publisher=Eurovision.tv | accessdate=2016-02-13}} * '''7''' **The annual [[Oslo Operaball]] takes place in [[Oslo]], Norway.{{cite web |url=http://www.oslointernationalclub.com/review-the-most-cosmopolitan-night-in-norway |title=Review: The most cosmopolitan night in Norway |publisher=OsloiInternationalClub.com |accessdate=2015-04-28}} **[[Knut Kristiansen]] and [[Bergen Big Band]] hold a release concert for the album ''Kuria Suite'' at [[Verftet]] in Bergen, Norway.{{cite web | url=https://bergenjazzforum.no/?p=3451 | title=BERGEN BIG BAND – "KURIA SUITE" - Sleppefest for Kuria Suite | publisher=BergenJazzforum.no | accessdate=2016-02-14}} * '''10''' - The [[Ojai Music Festival]] announces the appointment of [[Esa-Pekka Salonen]] as its music director for the 2018 season.{{cite press release|url=http://www.ojaifestival.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Ojai-Music-Festival-Announces-Future-Music-Directors-1.pdf |title=Ojai Music Festival Announces Future Music Directors Through 75th Festival |publisher=Ojai Music Festival |date=2016-02-10 |accessdate=2016-02-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216081349/http://www.ojaifestival.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/Ojai-Music-Festival-Announces-Future-Music-Directors-1.pdf |archivedate=2016-02-16 }} * '''13''' - The [[Dansk Melodi Grand Prix]] Final takes place at the [[Forum Horsens]] in [[Horsens]], Denmark.{{cite web | url=http://www.dr.dk/event/melodigrandprix | title=Melodi Grand Prix | publisher=[[DR (broadcaster)|DR]] | accessdate=2016-02-13}} [[Lighthouse X]] are selected to represent Denmark at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]].[http://eurovoix.com/2016/02/13/denmark-lighthouse-x-wins-dansk-melodi-grand-prix-2016/ "DENMARK: LIGHTHOUSE X WINS DANSK MELODI GRAND PRIX 2016"]. Accessed 13 February 2016 * '''15''' - It is announced that Swedish jazz saxophonist and composer [[Jonas Kullhammar]] is the recipient of the 2016 Gullinpriset (awarded in memory of the saxophonist [[Lars Gullin]] (1928 – 1976)).{{cite web | url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=94&artikel=6368750 | title=Jonas Kullhammar får Lars Gullin-priset | publisher=[[Sveriges Radio]] | accessdate=2016-02-16}} * '''16''' – [[Andreas Loven]] holds a release concert for the album ''District Six'' ([[Losen Records]]) at Victoria - National Jazz Scene in [[Oslo]].{{cite web |url=http://nasjonaljazzscene.no/arrangement |title=Andreas Loven Release! |language=Norwegian | publisher=NasjonalJazzscene.no |accessdate=2016-02-14}} * '''20''' - At Söngvakeppnin 2016 in [[Reykjavík]]'s Laugardalshöll, [[Greta Salóme]] is selected to represent Iceland at the Eurovision Song Contest, with the song "[[Hear Them Calling]]".[http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=greta_salome_to_represent_iceland "Greta Salóme to represent Iceland again!" Eurovision Song Contest website, 20 February 2016]. Accessed 22 February 2016 * '''26''' - A remix of [[Zara Larsson]]'s hit single "[[Lush Life (Zara Larsson song)|Lush Life]]", featuring [[Tinie Tempah]], is released, and soon becomes a top 10 hit internationally.{{cite web|url = https://itunes.apple.com/se/album/lush-life-feat.-tinie-tempah/id1086328951?l=en|title = iTunes Store (SE) - Music - Zara Larsson - Lush Life (feat. Tinie Tempah) [Remixes] - Single|access-date = 3 March 2016|date = 26 February 2016|work = [[iTunes Store]] (SE)}} * '''27''' - The [[Uuden Musiikin Kilpailu 2016]] Final takes place in Finland.{{cite web | url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=finlands_first_finalists_chosen | title=Finland's first finalists chosen | publisher=Eurovision.tv | accessdate=2016-02-13}} ===March=== * '''2''' – [[By:Larm]] 2016 starts in [[Oslo]] (March 2–5).{{cite web |url=http://www.globalpublicity.co.uk/bylarm-2015-highlights-dates-for-2016-announced |title=News |publisher=GlobalPublicity.co.uk |accessdate=2015-04-28}} * '''3''' ** [[Frode Alnæs]] holds a release concert for the album ''Kanestrøm'' (Øra Fonogram) at Victoria - National Jazz Scene in [[Oslo]].{{cite web |url=http://nasjonaljazzscene.no/arrangement/frode-alnaes-releasekonsert |title=Frode Alnæs - Releasekonsert! |language=Norwegian | publisher=NasjonalJazzscene.no |accessdate=2016-02-14}} ** The [[Oslo International Church Music Festival]] 2016 starts in [[Oslo]] (March 3–13).{{cite web |url=http://www.kirkemusikkfestivalen.no/index.php?kat_id=30 |title=Oslo Internationale Kirkemusikkfestival |publisher=[[Oslo International Church Music Festival]] |accessdate=2015-04-28}} * '''12''' - The final of Sweden's [[Melodifestivalen]] takes place.{{cite web | url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=sweden_melodifestivalen_2016_tour_announced | title=Sweden: Melodifestivalen 2016 tour announced | publisher=Eurovision.tv | accessdate=2016-02-13}} * '''17''' - Norwegian musician John Martin is convicted of the murder of his wife [[Natalia Strelchenko]], a Russian-born concert pianist, and is sentenced to life in prison.{{citation | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3499067/Musician-guilty-strangling-beating-death-world-renowned-concert-pianist-wife-jealous-rage.html | title = Musician found guilty of strangling and beating to death his world-renowned concert pianist wife in jealous rage | work = Daily Mail | date = 18 March 2016 | accessdate = }}{{citation | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-manchester-35863295 | title = Natalia Strelchenko murder: 'Jealous' husband John Martin jailed | work = BBC News | date = 21 March 2016 | accessdate = 22 March 2016}} * '''18''' – The [[Vossajazz]] event opens in Voss, Norway (March 18–20).{{cite web |url=http://vossajazz.no |title=Vossa Jazz 18. - 20. mars 2016 |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Bergensavisen]] |accessdate=2015-04-27}} * '''23''' – [[Inferno Metal Festival]] 2016 starts in [[Oslo]] (March 23–26).{{cite web |url=http://www.visitoslo.com/en/whats-on/festivals/major-festivals/inferno-metal-festival |title=Inferno Metal Festival |publisher=VisitOslo.com |accessdate=2015-04-28}} ===April=== * '''1''' - In the final of [[X Factor (Denmark season 9)|season 9 of Denmark's ''X Factor'']], the sister duo [[Embrace (duo)|Embrace]] emerge winners, obtaining 60% of the public vote.[http://www.dr.dk/event/xfactor/nyheder/x-factor-sejr-embrace-vandt-med-60-procent-af-stemmerne "X Factor-sejr: EMBRACE vandt med 60 procent af stemmerne" (Swedish)] * '''22''' - The final of [[The Voice of Finland (season 5)|season 5 of ''The Voice of Finland'']] is won by [[Suvi Åkerman]], mentored by [[Tarja Turunen]]. * '''23''' - The Gamlestaden Jazzfestival opens in [[Göteborg]], Sweden (April 23 – April 30).{{cite web | url=http://gmlstnjazz.com | title=GMLSTN JAZZ 2015 | publisher=GmlStnJazz.com | accessdate=2016-02-14}} ===May=== * '''14''' – The final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] takes place at the [[Ericsson Globe]] in Stockholm. Sweden, the only Scandinavian country to reach the final, finishes in 9th place. Finland, Iceland, Denmark and Norway are all eliminated in the semi-finals. * '''25''' – [[Festspillene i Bergen]] 2015 starts (May 25 – June 8).{{cite web |url=http://www.fib.no |title=Festspill 2015 -Aktuelt |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Festspillene i Bergen]] |accessdate=2015-06-11}} * '''26''' – [[Nattjazz]] starts in [[Bergen]] (May 26 – June 4).{{cite web|url=http://nattjazz.no |title=Nattjazz 26. mai - 4. juni USF Verftet 2016 - Takk for i år! |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Nattjazz]] |accessdate=2015-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150429010119/http://www.nattjazz.no/ |archivedate=2015-04-29 }} ===June=== * '''15''' – [[Bergenfest]] 2016 with headliner [[Sigur Rós]] (June 15 – 18).{{cite web |url=http://bergenfest.no/?gclid=Cj0KEQiA7rmzBRDezri2r6bz1qYBEiQAg-YEtlONX5J9tW2WeC-WggB2fZi58qsoRrL8ZSHfVBSPHO8aAm3O8P8HAQ |title=Bergenfest 15-18 juni 2016 |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Bergenfest]] |accessdate=2015-12-14}} * '''25''' - The 2016 [[Roskilde Festival]] opens with a performance by the [[Syrian National Orchestra for Arabic Music]] and [[Damon Albarn]] (June 25 - July 2).{{cite web | url=http://www.roskilde-festival.dk | title=Roskilde Festival 2016 | publisher=[[Roskilde Festival]] | accessdate=2016-02-14}} * '''30''' - [[Bråvalla Festival]] opens near [[Norrköping]], [[Sweden]]. ===July=== * '''3''' - The [[Copenhagen Jazz Festival]] 2016 opens (July 3–12).{{cite web | url=http://jazzfestival2016.com/events/jazz-festivals-in-europe/copenhagen-jazz-festival | title=COPENHAGEN JAZZ FESTIVAL - FROM 07/03/2016 TO 07/12/2016 AT MULTIPLE VENUES | publisher=[[Copenhagen Jazz Festival]] | accessdate=2016-02-14}} * '''6''' – The 17th [[Folk music festival of Siglufjordur]] opens in [[Siglufjordur]], Iceland (July 6 – 10).{{cite web | url=http://www.folkmusik.is/en | title=The Folk Music Festival of Siglufjordur | publisher=FolkMusik.is | accessdate=2017-01-30}} * '''14''' – [[G! Festival]] opens in [[Göta]], with a line-up including [[Songhoy Blues]], [[Lucy Rose]], [[Federspiel]] and the [[Hot 8 Brass Band]].[http://www.gfestival.fo/en/music/ G! Festival 2016 line-up] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305222651/http://www.gfestival.fo/en/music/ |date=2016-03-05 }}. Accessed 26 February 2016 * '''18''' – [[Moldejazz]] 2016 starts with [[Ola Kvernberg]] as artist in residence (August 18 – 23).{{cite web |url=http://www.moldejazz.no/2016 |title=Moldejazz: Ola Kvernberg |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Moldejazz]] |accessdate=2015-12-14}} * '''date unknown''' – Magnus Söderman (guitars) and Lawrence Dinamarca (drums) join [[Nightrage]]. ===August=== * '''14''' – [[Oslo Jazzfestival]] 2016 opens with a concert by the [[Jan Garbarek]] Group, featuring [[Trilok Gurtu]] (August 14 – 20).{{cite web |url=http://oslojazz.no |title=Oslo Jazzfestival: Åpningskonsert med Jan Garbarek |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Oslo Jazzfestival]] |accessdate=2015-11-20}} ===September=== * '''4''' – The 11th [[Punktfestivalen]] opens in [[Kristiansand, Norway]] (September 4–6).{{cite web | url=http://punktfestival.no | title=Punkt 2016 will take place from 1st to 3rd of September. | publisher=[[Punktfestivalen]] | accessdate=2016-04-26}} ===October=== * '''7''' – The 33rd [[Stockholm Jazz Festival]] opens in [[Stockholm]], Sweden (October 7–16).{{cite web | url=http://www.stockholmjazz.com | title=Stockholm Jazz Festival 7 – 16 oktober 2016 | publisher=[[Stockholm Jazz Festival]] | accessdate=2016-10-22}} * '''13''' – The 33rd [[DølaJazz]] opens in [[Lillehammer]], Norway (October 13–16).{{cite web | url=http://www.dolajazz.no | title=Dølajazz – Lillehammer Jazz Festival, 13 – 16 oktober 2016 | publisher=[[DølaJazz]] | accessdate=2016-09-29}} ===November=== * '''1''' - [[Hans Abrahamsen]] wins the [[Nordic Council Music Prize]] for his work ''[[let me tell you (composition)|Let Me Tell You]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.norden.org/en/news-and-events/news/hans-abrahamsen-wins-the-nordic-council-music-prize-for-201clet-me-tell-you201d|title=Hans Abrahamsen wins the Nordic Council Music Prize for "Let Me Tell You"|website=Nordic Cooperation|date=1 November 2016|access-date=10 October 2017}} * '''3''' - [[Tampere Music Festivals|Tampere Jazz Happening]] opens in Tampere, Finland (November 3–6).{{cite web | url=http://www.festivals.fi/festivaalit/tampere-jazz-happening-2/#.Vr9XufnhDIU | title=Tampere Jazz Happening: 03.11.2016 - 06.11.2016 | publisher=Festivals.fi | accessdate=2016-02-13}} * '''6''' – The [[Kongsberg Jazzfestival]] 2016 opens with [[Pat Metheny]] concert (August 6 – 9).{{cite web |url=http://www.moldejazz.no/2016 |title=Moldejazz: Ola Kvernberg |language=Norwegian |publisher=[[Moldejazz]] |accessdate=2015-12-14}} ===December=== * '''6''' - Danish band [[Lukas Graham]] are nominated for three [[Grammy Award]]s, including Record of the Year and Song of the Year for their single "7 Years".{{cite news|last1=Brown|first1=August|title=Lukas Graham grows up and finds Grammy acclaim with "7 Years"|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/la-et-ms-grammys-lukas-graham-20161206-story.html|accessdate=19 December 2016|work=Los Angeles Times|date=6 December 2016}} ==Albums released== ===January=== * '''8''' - [[Anders Hillborg]] - ''Sirens'', ''Cold Heat;'', ''Beast Sampler''{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/jan/27/hillborg-sirens-cold-heat-beast-sampler-etc-cd-review-oramo-salonen-zinman | title=Hillborg: Sirens; Cold Heat; Beast Sampler CD review – there's no doubt orchestras enjoy playing his music | work=The Guardian | author=Andrew Clements | date=2016-01-27 | accessdate=2016-01-23}} * '''22''' - [[Abbath (band)|Abbath]]'s debut album ''[[Abbath (album)|Abbath]]''{{cite web|title=New Song Premiere: ABBATH's 'Winter Bane'|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/new-song-premiere-abbaths-winter-bane/|publisher=[[Blabbermouth.net]]|accessdate=January 16, 2016|date=November 10, 2015}} * '''29''' ** ''What Was Said'' by [[Tord Gustavsen]] and his trio, featuring drummer [[Jarle Vespestad]] and German-Afghan vocalist Simin Tander ([[ECM Records]]{{cite web | url=https://www.ecmrecords.com/catalogue/1452516760/what-was-said-tord-gustavsen-simin-tander-jarle-vespestad | title=Tord Gustavsen - ''What was said'' - Jarle Vespestad, Simin Tander | publisher=[[ECM Records]] | accessdate=2016-02-01}} ** ''Momento'' by pianist [[Ayumi Tanaka|Ayumi Tanaka Trio]] (AMP) including with [[Christian Meaas Svendsen]] (bass) and [[Per Oddvar Johansen]] (drums).{{cite web | url=https://themusic.today/release/ayumi-tanaka-trio-memento/7437560 | title=Ayumi Tanaka Trio - Memento | publisher=TheMusic.Today | accessdate=2016-02-01}} ** ''[[Ghostlights]]'' by Finnish music project [[Avantasia]] ** ''High Noon'' by Finnish guitarist [[Kalle Kalima]] ([[ACT Music]]).{{cite web | url=https://www.actmusic.com/Kuenstler/Kalle-Kalima/High-Noon/High-Noon-CD | title=Kalle Kalima - ''High Noon'' - CD | publisher=[[ACT Music]] | accessdate=2016-02-13}} ** ''Some Other Time - A Tribute To Leonard Bernstein'' by [[Nils Landgren (musician)|Nils Landgren]] ([[ACT Music]]).{{cite web | url=https://www.actmusic.com/en/Artists/Nils-Landgren/Some-Other-Time-A-Tribute-To-Leonard-Bernstein/Some-Other-Time-CD | title=Nils Landgren: Some Other Time - A Tribute To Leonard Bernstein - CD | publisher=[[ACT Music]] | accessdate=2016-02-01}} ===February=== * '''1''' - ''Songbook'' by [[Lars Danielsson]] ([[ACT Music]]).{{cite web | url=https://www.actmusic.com/Kuenstler/Lars-Danielsson/Songbook/Songbook-20-Impromptus-For-Piano-1-Solo-Piece-For-Contrabass | title=Lars Danielsson ''Songbook'' | publisher=[[ACT Music]] | accessdate=2016-02-13}} * '''3''' - ''The Colorist & Emiliana Torrini'' by [[The Colorist]] & [[Emiliana Torrini]]{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/dec/08/the-colorist-emiliana-torrini-album-review-colourful-classical-and-contemporary-collisions | title=The Colorist & Emiliana Torrini album review – colourful classical and contemporary collisions | first=Harriet | last=Gibsone | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | date=2016-12-08| accessdate=2017-01-30}} * '''11''' - {{Synthesis|date=February 2018}} [[File:262212888 805b4a1711 o.jpg|thumb|250px|A Catalan-language sign in Valencia city calling for a boycott of Catalan products]] '''Anti-Catalanism''' ({{lang-ca|anticatalanisme}}, {{IPA-ca|ˌantikətələˈnizmə|IPA}}) is the collective name given to various alleged historical trends in [[Spain]] that have been hostile to [[:Category:Catalan culture|Catalan culture]] and [[Catalan traditions|traditions]].
In more recent times it is a term used to criticize political stances contrary to [[Catalan nationalism]] or [[Catalan independentism]], both inside and outside Catalonia.
==Description== In a historical context, anti-Catalanism expresses itself as a hostile attitude towards the [[Catalan language]], [[Catalan people|people]], [[Catalan traditions|traditions]] or anything identified with Catalonia. In a political context it may express itself as the reaction to a perceived intrusion of Catalan political nationalism into the area. In its most extreme circumstances, this may also be referred as '''Catalanophobia'''. Several political movements, known for organising [[boycott]]s of products from Catalonia, are also actively identified with anti-Catalanism. It is a controversial term in Spain since Catalan political parties which support political independence are often accused of conflating criticism of their stances and actions with an attack on all Catalans.
Anti-Catalanism in its most virulent form is mostly associated with [[far-right]] Spanish political parties. Fringe groups such as [[España 2000]] (none of which obtained more than 0.5% of the votes in the last general elections) object strongly to the autonomy enjoyed by Catalonia, claiming that the granting of autonomy to Catalonia and other regions will lead to the breakup of Spain{{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source.|date=November 2017}}.
Criticism of Catalan nationalism, is to be found throughout the Spanish political spectrum{{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source.|date=November 2017}}. However, such criticism does not usually imply hostility towards Catalonia itself, nor does it necessarily imply being against [[autonomous communities of Spain|regional autonomy in Spain]], or even the use of regional languages in the public domain. In fact, ''[[Ciutadans]]'' – which is possibly the most vocal of the Spanish political parties against the perceived excesses of regional nationalisms such as the Catalan – was created in Catalonia and has its national headquarters in [[Barcelona]]; this Catalan party – currently the largest party in the [[Parliament of Catalonia|Catalan regional parliament]] – is equally referred to by Catalan nationalists as "anti-Catalan",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naciodigital.cat/noticia/77161/terricabras/ciutadans/upyd/actuen/europa/militarment/anticatalans|title=NacióDigital: Terricabras: «Ciutadans i UpyD actuen a Europa militarment com anticatalans»|first=|last=NacióDigital|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> illustrating a certain tendency among pro-independence Catalan parties to interpret attacks on their political stance as xenophobic, populist or selfish attacks on all Catalans, nationalist or not.
In this regard, [[black list]]s of so-called "bad Catalans" (Catalan public figures who oppose Catalan separatism) have been published.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/ocio-y-cultura/lista-negra-malos-catalanes-5001061|title=Una lista negra de malos catalanes|first=Ernest|last=Alós|date=2 April 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> It should be added that Ciutadans has had links in the past to extremist groups.<ref>http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20090423/ciutadans-se-divide-tras-aprobar-acudir-europeas-coalicion-derechista-libertas/268846.shtml</ref> And more recently tried to pass a motion through parliament against the alleged indoctrination in Catalan, Balearic and Valencian schools.<ref>https://politica.elpais.com/politica/2017/10/17/actualidad/1508254151_637017.html</ref> Additionally such a distinction between "good Catalans" and "bad Catalans" is found in both sides of the issue, most recently by [[People's Party (Spain)|PP]] Catalan Leader Xavier Albiol who talked about mobilizing the majority of "good Catalans" when referring to those against independence.<ref>http://www.europapress.es/catalunya/noticia-albiol-dice-no-habra-independencia-llama-catalanes-bien-movilizarse-masivamente-20171004135404.html</ref> The prevalence of it is up for debate.
Adding to the confusion, Catalan nationalists have often labelled as 'anti-Catalan' previous policies of the Spanish or French state which, per se, were not directed specifically to the Catalan culture, but were a part of a general [[centralisation|centralist]] vision of politics.
Besides politics, anti-Catalanism is often also based on widespread perceived prejudices among regions of Spain. The stereotype of Catalans common throughout Spain involve a sense of them being industrious and excelling in entrepreneurship on the one side but also excessively individualistic, unfriendly, disloyal, snobbish or mean on the other side{{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source.|date=November 2017}}. This perception plays with alleged political realities, Catalonia often being accused of lack of solidarity with the poorer regions of Spain, marginalisation of the Spanish language and culture (e.g., ban on bullfighting, absence of Spanish-language public education), and historical discrimination or xenophobia against economic migrants from Andalusia, Extremadura or other Spanish regions. The degree to which these accusations are justified is debatable, particularly since the children and grandchildren of immigrants have successfully integrated into a multicultural Catalan society. It should also be added that these are usually based on politically motivated misinterpretations, Spanish-language education is possible under request<ref>https://elpais.com/ccaa/2016/09/01/catalunya/1472726417_392529.html</ref> and is in practice the language most used in education as shown by speaker rates.<ref>https://www.idescat.cat/pub/?id=ed&n=2568</ref> This also applies to the prohibition of Spanish language signs: though the law states that the main language of street signs should be Catalan, it does not forbid the use of Spanish along with it.<ref>http://consum.gencat.cat/qui_som/communicacio/codi-consum-catalunya/empreses-codi/index_es.html#2.1</ref>
However, arguments forwarded include that whereas the 20 most common surnames names in Catalonia proper are typical of the Spanish language,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/vida/20150219/54427403857/grafico-los-apellidos-mas-frecuentes-en-catalunya.html|title=Los apellidos más frecuentes en Catalunya|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> the majority of political seats and posts are held by people with typically Catalan language surnames, and some of those who do not have them 'Catalanise' them upon embarking on a political career. In particular it has been noted that a pool of Catalan language surnames held by 13% of the total Catalan population holds 40% of the politically designated jobs, which has been called an 'overrepresentation' or even 'hyperrepresentation' in the political elite of these Catalan families vs. the Catalan society as a whole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vozpopuli.com/actualidad/53736-la-endogamia-de-las-elites-nacionalistas-400-apellidos-copan-el-40-de-la-politica-catalana|title=La endogamia de las élites nacionalistas: 400 apellidos copan el 40% de la política catalana|first=|last=Vozpopuli|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref>
Anti-Catalanism has a local and distinctive manifestation in the [[Valencian Community]] called [[Blaverism]], a movement rejecting [[Joan Fuster]]'s concept of ''[[Països Catalans]]''.<ref>[[Xavier Coller]] [www.cairn.info/revue-pole-sud-2006-2-page-107.htm ''Collective identities and failed nationalism''], in ''Pôle Sud'' 2/2006 (n° 25), p. 107-136.</ref> Blaverism is best reflected in debates concerning the status of [[Valencian]] versus Catalan, even though this phenomenon has diminished greatly over the last 25 years. Also in [[Aragon]] there is an anti-Catalan movement that seeks to downplay the Catalan identity of [[La Franja]], thus the Aragonese regional parliament passed a law to avoid referring to the Catalan language as the language spoken in some parts of Aragon, forcing a neologism in its place,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtve.es/noticias/20130509/aragon-excluye-catalan-lenguas-oficiales-ahora-se-llama-lapao/660440.shtml|title=Aragón excluye al catalán de sus lenguas oficiales, ahora se llama Lapao - RTVE.es|date=9 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2013/05/09/actualidad/1368082767_046979.html|title=Las Cortes de Aragón aprueban llamar ‘lapao’ al catalán y ‘lapapyp’ al aragonés|first=Ediciones El|last=País|date=9 May 2013|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> even though this was later abrogated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavanguardia.com/politica/20160131/301787470825/gobierno-aragones-liquida-lapao.html|title=El Gobierno aragonés liquida el Lapao|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Nyatapola Temple.JPG|thumb|Nyatapola Temple located in [[Bhaktapur]], [[Nepal]], built in 1701–1702 CE]] [[File:Great Drigung Kagyud Lotus Stupa.JPG|thumb|The Great Drigung Kagyud Lotus Stupa in [[Lumbini]], [[Nepal]]]] [[File:Pashupatinaath0588.JPG|right|thumb|Traditional architecture of Kathmandu]] '''Nepali architecture''' or '''Nepalese architecture''' is a unique strain of art and practicality.It is famous all over the world. Situated in between the trade routes of India and Tibet and China, Nepali architecture reflects influences from both these cultural strongholds. The [[pagoda]] architectural tradition figures prominently among [[Hindu temple]]s in the country. The pagoda architectural tradition as well, along with the [[Tibetan Buddhist architecture|Tibetan tradition]] of [[Buddhist architecture]] and the [[stupa]] in contrast is widely used among [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] temples throughout the country.Mugal style ,summit style,dome style also have great scope in Nepal. [[File:Chhahara, Nepal-WLV-0378.jpg|thumb|Traditional house in Nepal]] ==Architectural Ensemble== The Architectural Ensemble is a motley assembly of the following general structures. Each type is unique and distinctive in character and utility. However, all are linked in a common techniques and styles: * Patis (no link) * [[Pauwa]]s (no link) * [[Stupa]]s * [[Chaitya]]s * [[jahru]]s (no link) * [[Palace]]s * [[monastery|Monasteries]] * [[Temple]]s * Residential [[house]]s *Nothing [[rest house]]s

{{Italic title}} '''''Babysan''''' was a comic created by American artist [[Bill Hume (cartoonist)|Bill Hume]] while he was stationed in Japan in the 1950s. The comic depicts American sailors interacting with a pin-up style Japanese woman named Babysan. The title comes from the word "baby" an affectionate term Americans use and "san" which is an honorary term used by the Japanese. It translates literally to Miss Baby. The comic became incredibly popular with United States service members in Japan by mixing good humor with culture, language, and sex. Babysan attempted to show some of the give and take between American and Japanese cultures during the occupational era. Anything but political, the comic plays on misunderstanding and sexuality. "I didn't invent Babysan, I just reported life as it was."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clark |first1=Bill |title='Art talent' has taken Hume on a fascinating journey |url=http://archive.columbiatribune.com/2006/mar/20060317Life002.asp |website=columbiatribune.com |accessdate=16 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052718/http://archive.columbiatribune.com/2006/mar/20060317Life002.asp |archivedate=4 March 2016 }}</ref>
==History== Bill Hume was a member of the U.S Navy during World War II (1942–1945). He left the Navy in 1945 and married. In 1951, he was recalled to be part of the occupying force in Japan.<ref>{{cite web|last1=|title=Bill Hume, 1916-2009|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/obituaries/bill-hume/article_f5713060-22bf-517c-93f3-81a16aa8c84c.html|website=Columbiatribune.com|accessdate=16 July 2015}}</ref> Hume served as a petty officer in charge of maintaining good order and discipline and was also the editor of the station newspaper, ''The Oppaman''. Through his observations of life in Japan, the effects American sailors were having on the culture, and the effects the Japanese culture was having on the sailors Hume created Babysan, originally a pinup poster, to help boost morale.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hume|first1=Bill|title=Babysan: A Private Look at the Japanese Occupation|date=1953|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle Co.|location=Rutland, Vt|OCLC=9529575|page=6}}</ref> Babysan became a hit with the sailors of Fleet Airforce Service Squadron 120 and this popularity spread to the [[Navy Times]] and finally to the United States when servicemen began returning home. Hume returned to the United States in 1952, teamed up with John Annarino, and four books based on Babysan were published shortly after.<ref>{{cite book|last=Harvey|first= Robert C.|title=Insider Histories of Cartooning: Rediscovering Forgotten Famous Comics and Their Creators|publisher=University of Mississippi|date=2014|ISBN=9781628461435|pages=151–161}}</ref>
==Content== Babysan gave a view of post-war Japan from the eyes of an American servicemember. Their love of American movies, American dance, and western clothing comes in stark contrast to the society of the recent past. Bill Hume rarely, if ever, depicts Japanese men in his comics and these cultural changes may or may not have impacted them at the time but when the Japanese women began adopting them.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shibusawa|first1=Naoko|title=America's Geisha Ally: Reimagining the Japanese Enemy|date=2010|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674057470}}</ref> the American servicemen felt more relaxed and accepting. Although naive and innocent the character of Babysan was able to teach Americans a little bit about customary practices such as taking off shoes before entering a house, the [[hibatchi]], the [[kimono]], food, and money. It also included common Japanese words and a rudimentary explanation of writing even though some arrogant American sailors already seemed to know it all.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hume|first1=Bill|title=Babysan A Private Look at the Japanese Occupation|date=1953|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle Co|location=Rutland, VT|page=89}}</ref> In addition to entertaining the troops, Babysan also provided a glimpse of what to expect and how they might be perceived in their new home.
This semi-pornographic comic often featured Babysan partially nude and flirting. In one comic, she reminded creator Bill Hume that "Japanese girls like to wear clothes, too."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hume|first1=Bill|title=Babysan's World: The Hume'n Slant on Japan|date=1954|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle Co.|location=Rutland, VT|OCLC=46486948|page=116}}</ref> Servicemen may have imagined ''Cio-Cio San'' in Puccini's [[Madame Butterfly]] as the typical Japanese girl but what they got was instead was Babysan.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shibusawa|first1=Naoko|title=America's Geisha Ally: Reimagining the Japanese Enemy|date=2010|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674057470|pages=34–36}}</ref> This Japanese woman was self-motivated with her own problems and desires. Tight fitting clothing, blunt talk, and comfort with nudity made Babysan irresistible to servicemen of every rank and when they got jealous they accused her of "butterflying". This term meant being unfaithful but Babysan never accepted this description, she would disagree in her broken English and say that she had not butterflied, she had changed her mind. Babysan also desired money. She goes from one serviceman to another flirting asking questions like "Why you all time bring candy- why never bring okane(money)?"(33) or "Why never have liberty on payday?". (83) This was not prostitution however. It was payment for services to be sure but "Babysan never forgot the acts of kindness on the part of the American. She decided...to devote herself to the part of the American...There wasn't much sense in restricting her charms to one."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hume|first1=Bill|title=Babysan A Private Look at the Japanese Occupation|date=1953|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle Co|location=Rutland, VT|page=7}}</ref> She entertained them with her beauty, her femininity, her charm, and her energy. And unlike Cio-Cio San, Babysan was not upset when Americans left for home, as she was waving goodbye to them she was already looking towards the future and another serviceman.
==Impact== Babysan made light of the tumultuous situation in Japan during the 1940s and 50s. Although not intended to be a textbook on Japanese custom and tradition Hume's works certainly contained elements of both. These were combined with some of charming things in Japan including the most charming thing to the United States servicemen according to Hume, the Japanese girl.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hume|first1=Bill|title=Babysan's World: The Hume'n Slant on Japan|date=1954|publisher=Charles E. Tuttle Co.|location=Rutland, VT|page=16}}</ref> Babysan disarmed the sailors and soldiers with her beauty and ability to adopt new things and through her they were able to enjoy the food, the language, and the culture during their short tours in Japan. It is not a widely known work but among many in the field, it is highly respected.<ref>{{cite book|last=Harvey|first= Robert C.|title=Insider Histories of Cartooning: Rediscovering Forgotten Famous Comics and Their Creators|publisher=University of Mississippi|date=2014|ISBN=9781628461435|pages=151–161}}</ref>

[[File:Moneda de 2 Euros de Finlàndia.JPG|thumb|[[2 euro coins|€2 coin]], composed of a core of nickel-[[brass]], ringed by a [[copper-nickel]] alloy.]]
'''Bi-metallic coins''' are [[coin]]s consisting of two (''[[bi-]]'') [[metal]]s or [[alloy]]s, generally arranged with an outer ring around a contrasting center. Common circulating examples include the [[Indian 10-rupee coin|₹10]], [[1 euro coins|€1]], [[2 euro coins|€2]], [[Polish zloty|2 and 5 PLN]], [[Czech koruna|50 CZK]], [[Hungarian forint|100 and 200 HUF]], [[Bulgarian Lev|1 and 2 BGN]], [[United Kingdom|British]] [[One pound (British coin)|£1]] and [[Two pounds (British coin)|£2]], [[Canada|Canadian]] [[Two Dollar Coin (Canada)|$2]], [[South Africa]]n [[South African rand|R5]], [[Turkey|Turkish]] [[Turkish lira|1 lira]], [[Rupiah|IDR 1K]], [[Hong Kong]] [[Hong Kong ten-dollar coin|$10]], [[Argentina|Argentine]] [[Argentine peso|$1]], [[Brazilian real#Second series (1998–present)|Brazilian R$1]] [[Philippine]] [[Philippine ten peso coin|₱10]], and all [[Mexico|Mexican]] coins of [[Mexican peso|$1]] or higher denomination. [[File:20franctrimetalrev.jpg|thumbnail|1992 French 20-francs tri-metallic coin, composed of three components: the outer ring, the second ring and the center plug.]] [[File:Kingtutcoinobv without background.png|thumbnail|2008 "[[King Tutankhamun]]" bi-metallic 1 [[Egyptian pound]] coin.]]
Bi-metallic coins have been issued for a long time, with known examples dating from the 17th century, while the Roman Empire issued special-occasion, large medallions with a center of bronze or copper and an outer ring of [[orichalcum]], starting with the reign of [[Hadrian]]. The [[silver-center cent]] [[pattern coin|pattern]] produced by the [[United States]] in 1792 is another example. In the 1830s and 1840s, British medalist Joseph Moore produced large numbers of bi-metallic "penny model" and less common "halfpenny model" tokens, as a proposal to replace the relatively large [[Penny (British pre-decimal coin)|penny]] and [[Halfpenny (British pre-decimal coin)|halfpenny]] coins. Though not [[legal tender]], Moore's tokens were circulated widely and accepted at face value by many merchants. Despite their popularity, the [[Royal Mint]] rejected the proposal, and did not reduce the size of the penny and halfpenny until [[Decimal Day|decimalization]].
In recent times, the first circulating bi-metallic coin was the [[Italy|Italian]] 500 [[Italian lira|lire]], first issued in 1982. [[Morocco]], with its 5-[[Moroccan dirham|dirham]]s coin in 1987; [[France]], with a 10-[[French franc|franc]]s coin in 1992; [[Monaco]], with a 10 [[Monegasque franc|franc]]s; [[Thailand]], with a 10 [[Thai baht|baht]], in 1988; and [[Hong Kong]], with a $10 coin, in 1993, [[Hungary]], with a 100-[[Hungarian forint|forint]] coin in 1996, and [[Brazil]] with the 1 [[Brazilian real|real]] coin issued bi-metallic coins for circulation all based on the minting process of the Italian 500 lire coin. [[India]] introduced 10-[[Indian rupee|rupee]] bi-metallic coins in 2009 that are dated 2006 (minted at [[Noida]]). Since 1996, [[Canada]] has also produced bi-metallic [[Canadian dollar|$2 coins]] (nicknamed "[[Toonie|toonies]]"). [[Great Britain]] has issued a bi-metallic 2-[[British pound|pound]] coin since 1997; and [[Singapore]] has issued a bi-metallic 1-[[Singapore dollar|dollar]] coin since 2013.
The first ever tri-metallic circulating coins were 20-francs coins introduced in France and Monaco in 1992. These were similar to the corresponding bi-metallic 10-francs coins, but had two rings instead of one.
As well as circulating coins, where they are generally restricted to high-denomination coins, bi-metallic coins are often used in [[Commemorative coin|commemorative issues]], often made of [[precious metals]]. For example, the only bi-metallic coin of the [[United States]] is the [[2000 Library of Congress bimetallic ten dollar coin|$10 Library of Congress commemorative]], made of a [[gold]] ring around a [[platinum]] center. They are used primarily as a way of securing against [[coin counterfeiting]].
The manufacturing process is similar to that of ordinary coins, except that two blanks (the inner and the outer) are struck at the same time, deforming the separate blanks sufficiently to hold them together.
==Countries== [[Image:Bimetallic coins usage worldwide.svg|thumb|center|500px|Countries with bimetallic coins in circulation. Ochre denotes more than one bimetallic coin in use. Teal denotes that non-bimetallic coin of the same value circulates alongside the bimetallic coin.]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2014}}
When annotating [[chess]] games, commentators frequently use widely recognized annotation symbols. [[Question mark]]s and [[exclamation point]]s that denote a move as bad or good are ubiquitous in chess literature.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shatranj.us/files/AnalysisSymbols.pdf |title=Chess Analysis Symbols |publisher=C&O Family Chess Center |website=chesscenter.net}}</ref> Some publications intended for an international audience, such as the ''[[Chess Informant]]'', have a wide range of additional symbols that transcend language barriers.
The common symbols for evaluating the merits of a move are "??", "?", "?!", "!?", "!", and "!!". In these cases, the corresponding symbol is juxtaposed in the text immediately after the move (e.g. Re7? or Kh1!?, see [[algebraic chess notation]]).
Use of these annotation symbols is subjective, as different annotators use the same symbols differently. Moreover, an annotator's use of symbols is often influenced by the player's strength: a positional misjudgment that an annotator might give a "??" if played by a strong [[Grandmaster (chess)|grandmaster]] might pass unremarked if played by a beginner.
Annotators' use of punctuation also may possibly be influenced by the result of the game regardless of the actual quality of the move; this tendency is sometimes referred to as "annotation by result". {{algebraic notation|pos=toc}}
== Evaluation symbols ==
=== Moves {{anchor|Move}} === Move evaluation symbols, by increasing effectiveness of the move:
==== ?? (Blunder) {{anchor|??|Blunder}} ==== {{Main|Blunder (chess)}} The double question mark "??" indicates a [[blunder (chess)|blunder]], a very bad mistake. Typical moves which receive double question marks are those that overlook a [[Tactics (chess)|tactic]] that wins substantial material or overlook a [[checkmate]]. A "??"-worthy move usually results in an immediately lost position. Occasionally, the sign is used for a move which transforms a won position into a draw, perhaps because the annotator feels that the mistake is unworthy of the player's skill level. They occur at all levels of play to all human competitors.
==== ? (Mistake) {{anchor|?|Mistake}} ==== A single question mark "?" after a move indicates that the annotator thinks that the move is a poor one that should not be played. These often lead to loss of tempo or material. The nature of the mistake may be more strategic than tactical; in some cases, the move receiving a question mark may be one for which it is difficult to find a refutation. A move that overlooks a forthcoming brilliant [[Combination (chess)|combination]] from the opponent would rarely receive more than one question mark, for example.
Whether a single or double question mark is used is subjective and may depend on the player's strength. For instance, if a beginner makes a serious strategic error (for instance, accepting gratuitous pawn weaknesses or [[Exchange (chess)|exchanging]] into a lost [[Chess endgame|endgame]]) or overlooks a tactical sequence, this might be explained by the beginner's lack of skill, and be given only one question mark. If a master were to make the same move, some annotators might use the double question mark to indicate that one would never expect a player of the master's strength to make such a weak move.
==== ?! (Dubious move) {{anchor|?!|Dubious move|Dubious}} ==== This symbol is similar to the "!?" (below) but usually indicates that the annotator believes the move to be objectively bad, albeit hard to refute. The "?!" may also indicate that the annotator believes the move is deserving of criticism but not bad enough to warrant a "?". A sacrifice leading to a dangerous attack which the opponent should be able to defend against if he plays well may receive a "?!". Alternatively, this may denote a move that is objectively bad, but sets up an attractive trap.
==== !? (Interesting move) {{anchor|!?|Interesting move|Interesting}} ==== The "!?" is one of the more controversial symbols. Different books have slightly varying definitions. Among the definitions are "interesting, but perhaps not the best move", "move deserving attention", "enterprising move" and "risky move". Usually it indicates that the move leads to exciting or wild play but that the objective evaluation of the move is unclear. It is also often used when a player sets a cunning trap in a lost position. Typical moves receiving a "!?" are those involving speculative sacrifices or dangerous attacks which might turn out to be strategically deficient.
[[Andrew Soltis]] jokingly called "!?" the symbol of the lazy annotator who finds a move interesting but cannot be bothered to work out whether it is good or bad.<ref>''Chess to Enjoy-Eternal Questions'', published in ''Chess Life'', March 2000, pp. 12-13.</ref>
==== ! (Good move) {{anchor|!|Good move|Good}} ==== While question marks indicate bad moves, exclamation points ("!") indicate good moves—especially ones which are surprising or involve particular skill. Hence annotators are usually somewhat conservative with the use of this symbol.
Once the players start making good choices when faced with difficult decisions, however, a few moves may receive exclamation points from annotators. Typical moves receiving exclamation points are strong {{chessgloss|theoretical novelty|opening novelties}}, well-timed breakthroughs, sound [[Sacrifice (chess)|sacrifices]], and moves that avoid falling into [[Swindle (chess)|traps]].
==== ‼ (Brilliant move) {{anchor|‼|!!|Brilliant move|Brilliant}} ==== The double exclamation point ("‼") is used for very strong moves such as sound sacrifices of large amounts of material and counter-intuitive moves that prove very powerful. For example, in what is known as the [[The Game of the Century (chess)|Game of the Century]], 13-year-old [[Bobby Fischer]]'s decision to sacrifice his queen for a strategic attack was awarded by annotators a double exclamation point. <ref name="move 17, Game of the Century">{{cite web |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Game_of_the_Century_(chess)#cite_note-12 |website=wikipedia |accessdate=7 September 2018|title=The Game of the Century (chess) |date=2018-07-11 }}</ref>
==== Others ==== A few writers have used three or more exclamation points ("!!!") for an exceptionally brilliant move. For example, in [http://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1119679 Rotlewi-Rubinstein 1907], [[Hans Kmoch]] awarded Rubinstein's 22...Rxc3 three exclamation points. Likewise, an exceptionally bad blunder may be awarded three or more question marks ("???"). The general consensus among chess writers is that these symbols are unnecessary.
A few writers have used unusual combinations of question marks and exclamation points (e.g. "!!?", "?!?", "??!") for particularly unusual or controversial moves, but these have no generally accepted meaning, and are typically used for humorous or entertainment purposes.
Occasionally an annotation symbol may be put in parentheses, e.g. "(?)", "(!)". Different writers have used these in different ways; for example [[Simon Webb (chess player)|Simon Webb]] used "(?)" to indicate a move which is objectively sound, but was in his opinion a poor psychological choice, while [[Robert Hübner]] (see below) used it to indicate a move which is inaccurate and makes the player's task more difficult.
=== Alternative uses === There are some systems which use these symbols in different ways.
==== Nunn's convention ==== In his 1992 book ''Secrets of Rook Endings'' and other books in the series (''Secrets of Minor-Piece Endings'' and ''Secrets of Pawnless Endings''), [[John Nunn]] uses these symbols in a more specific way in the context of [[Chess endgame|endgames]] where the optimal line of play can be determined with certainty:
* ! {{pad|0.5em}}The only move which maintains the current evaluation of the position: if the position is theoretically [[draw (chess)|drawn]], this is the only move which does not lose; if the position is theoretically won, this is the only move which secures the win. An "!" is used no matter how trivial the move in question; the only exception is if it is the only legal move. * !! {{pad|0.5em}}A particularly difficult-to-find "!" move. * ? {{pad|0.5em}}A move which negatively affects the evaluation of the position: if the position had been drawn before the move, it is now lost; if won before the move, it is now drawn or lost. * ?? {{pad|0.5em}}An obviously bad "?" move. * !? {{pad|0.5em}}A move which makes the opponent's task harder or one's own task easier; for example, in a theoretically lost position, a move which forces the opponent to find several "!" moves in order to win. * ?! {{pad|0.5em}}A move which makes the opponent's task easier or one's own task harder; for example, in a theoretically won position, a move which requires several subsequent "!" moves in order to win {{Harvcol|Nunn|1999}}.
This convention has been used in some later works, such as ''Fundamental Chess Endings'' and ''Secrets of Pawn Endings'' by [[Karsten Müller]] and [[Frank Lamprecht]], but it can be safely assumed the convention is not being used unless there is a specific note otherwise. The Nunn convention cannot be used to annotate full games because the exact evaluation of a position is generally impractical to compute.
In 1959, Euwe and Hooper made the same use of the question mark, "... a decisive error...".<ref>Euwe & Hooper, p. viii</ref>
==== Hübner's approach ==== [[Germany|German]] [[Grandmaster (chess)|grandmaster]] [[Robert Hübner]] prefers an even more specific and restrained use of move evaluation symbols: "I have attached question marks to the moves which change a winning position into a drawn game, or a drawn position into a losing one, according to my judgment; a move which changes a winning game into a losing one deserves two question marks ... I have distributed question marks in brackets to moves which are obviously inaccurate and significantly increase the difficulty of the player's task ... There are no exclamation marks, as they serve no useful purpose. The best move should be mentioned in the analysis in any case; an exclamation mark can only serve to indicate the personal excitement of the commentator."<ref>''Twenty-five Annotated Games'', published by Edition Marco, Verlag Arno Nickel, Berlin, 1996, pp. 7-8.</ref>
==== Chess composition ==== When the solution to a certain [[chess problem]] is given, there are also some conventions that have become a common practice: * {{chessprobgloss|key|Key}} move is marked with at least one "!" * {{chessprobgloss|try|Try}} move is marked with "?" * Refutation to a try move is marked with "!" * When {{chessprobgloss|dual|dual avoidance}} is a part of the thematic content of a problem, avoided duals (if listed) are marked with "?"
=== Positions {{anchor|Position|Pos eval|Pos}} === These symbols indicate the strategic balance of the game position:
==== = (Equal) {{anchor|=|Equal|Equality}} ==== Even position: White and Black have more or less equal chances.
==== +/= or ⩲ (Slight plus for White) {{anchor|+/=|Slight plus for White}} ==== Slight advantage: White has slightly better chances.
==== =/+ or ⩱ (Slight plus for Black) {{anchor|=/+|Slight plus for Black}} ==== Slight advantage: Black has slightly better chances.
==== +/− or ± (Clear plus for White) {{anchor|+/−|±|Clear plus for White}} ==== Clear advantage: White has much better chances. It is also written as ±; the other similar symbols can be written in this style as well.
==== −/+ or ∓ (Clear plus for Black) {{anchor|−/+|∓|Clear plus for Black}} ==== Clear advantage: Black has much better chances. It is also written as ∓; the other similar symbols can be written in this style as well.
==== + − (Decisive advantage for White) {{anchor|+−|Decisive advantage for White}} ==== Decisive advantage: White has a winning advantage.
==== − + (Decisive advantage for Black) {{anchor|−+|Decisive advantage for Black}} ==== Decisive advantage: Black has a winning advantage.
==== ∞ (Unclear) {{anchor|∞|Unclear}} ==== Unclear position: It is unclear who (if anyone) has an advantage. Often used when a position is highly asymmetrical, e.g. Black has a ruined pawn structure but dangerous active piece-play.
==== =/∞ (Compensation) {{anchor|=/∞|Compensation}} ==== With compensation: Whoever is down in {{chessgloss|material}} has compensation for it. Can also denote a position that is unclear, but appears to the annotator to be approximately equal.
== Other symbols {{anchor|Others}} == There are other symbols used by various chess engines and publications, such as ''[[Chess Informant]]'' and ''[[Encyclopaedia of Chess Openings]]'', when annotating moves or describing positions.
=== Move-related === * <big>⌓</big> {{pad|0.5em}}Better: Indicates a better move than the one played. * <big>□</big> {{pad|0.5em}}Only: The only reasonable move, or the only move available. * Δ {{pad|0.5em}}Idea: Indicates the future plan this move supports. * ∇ {{pad|0.5em}}Countering: Indicates the opponent's plan this move defends against. * TN or N {{pad|0.5em}}Novelty: A move that is a {{chessgloss|theoretical novelty}}.
=== Positions or conditions === * ↑ {{pad|0.5em}}Initiative: Indicates an advantage in [[initiative (chess)|initiative]]. * → {{pad|0.5em}}Attack: With an {{chessgloss|attack}}. * <big>⇄</big> {{pad|0.5em}}Counterplay: Indicates that the player has {{chessgloss|counterplay}}. * <big>↻</big> or ↑↑{{pad|0.5em}}Development: Indicates a lead in {{chessgloss|development}}. * <big><big>○</big></big> {{pad|0.5em}}Space: Indicates more {{chessgloss|space}} owned by one player. * <big>⊕</big> {{pad|0.5em}}[[Time trouble]], a.k.a. Zeitnot: Indicates the player had little time remaining on their clock. * <big>⊙</big> {{pad|0.5em}}[[Zugzwang]]

{{For|the city|Kraków}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[File:Arsen 5104 f14 detail2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Poulaines worn in Burgundy ca. 1470]]
'''Crakows''' or '''crackowes''' were a style of shoes with extremely long toes very popular [[1400–1500 in fashion|in the 15th century]]. They were so named because the style was thought to have originated in [[Kraków]], then the capital of [[Poland]]. They are also sometimes known as poulaines or pikes,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pratt|first1=Lucy|last2=Woolley|first2=Linda|title=Shoes|date=2008|publisher=V&A Publications|location=London|isbn=978-1-851-77537-8|pages=12–13|edition=Pbk.}}</ref> though the term ''poulaine'', as in ''souliers a la poulaine'', "shoes in the Polish fashion", referred to the long pointed beak of the shoe, not the shoe itself.<ref name="Carlson">Carlson, I. Marc. 2001, [http://www.personal.utulsa.edu/~marc-carlson/shoe/APP5.HTM "Medieval European Long Toed Shoes"], "Footwear of The Middle Ages", 2001</ref>
==History== Long toed shoes had been popular in Europe at different times, first appearing in the archaeological record in the 12th century and falling in and out of fashion periodically before reaching their most exaggerated form in the third quarter of the 15th century and falling out of fashion in the 1480s.<ref name="stt">Goubitz, Olaf; van Driel-Murray, Carol; Groenman-Van Waateringe, Willy. 2001 "Stepping through time : archaeological footwear from prehistoric times until 1800": Zwolle [Netherlands] : Stichting Promotie Archeologie</ref><ref name="s+p">Grew, F. and de Neergaard, M. 1988. ''Shoes and Pattens. Medieval Finds from Excavations in London'': 2. London: HMSO, pp. 88–9.</ref>
The arrival of this fashion in England is traditionally associated with the marriage of [[Richard II]] and [[Anne of Bohemia]] in 1382. An anonymous 'monk of Evesham' recorded in 1394: "With this queen there came from Bohemia into England those accursed vices (English ''Cracowys'' or ''Pykys'') half a yard in length, thus it was necessary for them to be tied to the shin with chains of silver before they could walk with them."
However, there are indications they were worn as early as the 1360s. The author of the ''Eulogium Historiarum'' describes men of this period as wearing "points on their shoes as long as your finger that are called crakowes; more suitable as claws... for demons than as ornaments for men."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chambers|first1=Mark|last2=Sylvester|first2=Louise|editor1-last=Hamling|editor1-first=Tara|editor2-last=Richardson|editor2-first=Catherine|title=Everyday Objects: Medieval and Early Modern Material Culture and its Meanings|chapter=Lexicological Confusion and Medieval Clothing Culture: Redressing Medieval Dress with the Lexis of Cloth and Clothing in Britain Project|date=2010|publisher=Ashgate Pub.|location=Farnham, Surrey, England|isbn=0754666379|pages=71–84|edition=Repr.}}</ref>
14th century poulaine-toed shoes found in London were found only in men's sizes,<ref name="s+p" /> but 15th century art shows them being worn by both men and women, with the toes of men's shoes being the most extravagantly long. They were a controversial fashion and faced criticism from several quarters. In 1368, [[Charles V of France]] issued an edict banning their construction and use in Paris. An English poem from 1388 complained that men were unable to kneel in prayer because their toes were too long.<ref name="scott">{{cite book|last1=Scott|first1=Margaret|title=Medieval Clothing and Costumes: Displaying Wealth and Class in Medieval Times|date=2004|publisher=Rosen Central|location=New York|isbn=082393991X|edition=1st}}</ref> In 1463, [[Edward IV]] passed a [[sumptuary law]] restricting anyone "under the state of a Lord, Esquire, [or] Gentleman" from wearing poulaines over the length of two inches. In 1465, they were banned in England altogether, so that all cordwainers and cobblers within the City of London were prohibited from making shoes with pikes more than two inches long.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Grew|first1=Francis|last2=de Neergaard|first2=Margrethe|title=Shoes and Pattens|date=2002|publisher=Boydell Press|location=Rochester, NY|isbn=0851158382|page=117|edition=New}}</ref>
The poulaine inspired later footwear fashions, such as the 1950s [[Winklepicker]] boots.
==Features== ===Stuffing=== Poulaine toes were packed with stuffing to provide rigidity and help them hold their shape. Surviving examples from medieval London have the points stuffed with [[moss]].<ref name="stt" /> An Italian chronicler noted in 1388 that they were also sometimes stuffed with horsehair.<ref name="scott"/>
===Tying up the toes=== Although there is no archaeological or medieval iconographic evidence to support the idea that the toes were ever tied up to the leg,<ref name="Carlson" /> as noted earlier, there is direct literary evidence dating from 1394 which states that this was the practice at the time these shoes were introduced into England. Additionally, the practice is mentioned by the antiquarian [[John Stow]] in his 1698 publication ''A Survey of London'', where he wrote: {{cquote | "In Distar Lane, on the north side thereof, is the [[shoemaking|Cordwainer's]] Hall, which company were made a brotherhood or fraternity in the eleventh of Henry IV. Of these cordwainers, I read, that since the fifth of [[Richard II of England|Richard II]] (when he took to wife [[Anne of Bohemia|Anne]], daughter to [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Wenceslaus]] [sic], King of [[Bohemia]]), by her example the English people had used piked shoes, tied to their knees with silken laces, or chains of silver or gilt, wherefore in the fourth of Edward IV it was ordained and proclaimed that beaks of [[shoe|shoon]] and boots should not pass the length of two inches, upon pain of cursing by the clergy, and by Parliament to pay twenty shillings for every pair. And every cordwainer that shod any man or woman on the Sunday, to pay thirty shillings".<ref>John Stow, 'Bredstreete warde', in A Survey of London. Reprinted From the Text of 1603, ed. C L Kingsford (Oxford, 1908), pp. 344-352 http://www.british-history.ac.uk/no-series/survey-of-london-stow/1603/pp344-352 [accessed 22 July 2015]</ref>}}
However, given that John Stow was writing over 100 years after the shoes fell out of fashion, and the lack of rigorous historical research in the writings of the time, he cannot be considered a reliable source. His record of Act 4 of Edward IV is exaggerated - the actual act does mention restrictions in length, but not monetary penalties, parliament or clergy: {{cquote | Nulle persone Cordewaner ou Cobeler .. face.. ascuns soler galoges ou husend oveqe ascun pike ou poleine qe passera la longuer ou mesure de deux poutz.<ref name="Carlson" />}}
[[File:2008-08 archeon schnabelschuh.JPG|thumb|Poulaine at the shoemaker of [[Archeon, Netherlands|Archeon]]]]
===Poulaines as overshoes=== Overshoes made from leather or cork, called [[pattens]], were frequently worn with late medieval shoes both indoors and outdoors. The shape of pattens reflected the style of shoes in different periods, and pattens during the period where poulaine toes were fashionable have matching long toes. These pattens would have supported the toe of the shoes if required.
===Toe length=== Archaeological evidence in the form of surviving shoe soles shows that the length of the point beyond the toes of the foot was rarely, if ever, more than 50% of the length of the foot.<ref name="stt" /><ref name="s+p" /> This is consistent with depictions of highly fashionable European men from the third quarter of the 15th century when poulaine toes were at the height of their popularity.
[[File:Sempach Schilling.jpg|thumb|300px|Depiction of the [[Battle of Sempach]] in the [[Luzerner Schilling]], showing a large pile of shoe-tips on a hill in the upper-left of the illustration (1513)]] As with many items of high fashion the most extreme examples were worn by the upper classes. In periods when poulaine toes were popular most shoes were somewhat pointed, even those used during warfare. There is clear evidence from the [[Battle of Sempach]] that in certain periods soldiers on campaign wore shoes with toes so long as to interfere with the wearer's ability to run. In that battle, it became necessary for the knights of [[Leopold III, Duke of Austria]] to dismount and fight on foot, and because they did not have time to prepare for the engagement, they were forced to cut off the tips of their poulaines. The Swiss chroniclers report how a huge pile of these shoe-tips was found in a heap after the battle, and they are also depicted in the background of the battle scene in the [[Lucerne Chronicle]] of 1513.
[[File:HJRK A 62 - Armoured shoes of Maximilian I, 1485.jpg|thumb|left|Sabatons of [[Emperor Maximilian I]], c. 1485]] A surviving pair of [[sabatons]] belonging to Emperor Maximilian have extremely long poulaines, but they were used only on horseback and in this case the long points were detachable from the sabatons for foot combat. The catches can be seen over the area of the big toe.
